title: Modeling a Periodic Context-Jump Rope, Part A

content.description:
The figure shows two people turning a jump rope at a constant rate as a third person attempts to jump over the rope as it passes below their feet. Point <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> is located in the middle of the jump rope and is touching the ground at time <math alttext="t equals 0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math> seconds. The next time that point <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> touches the ground is at time <math alttext="t equals 1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> second. The maximum height of <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> above the ground is <math alttext="78" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>78</mn></math> inches. As the rope turns, the height of <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> above the ground periodically increases and decreases.

The sinusoidal function <math alttext="h" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi></math> models the height of point <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> above the ground, in inches, as a function of time <math alttext="t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math>, in seconds.
content.question:
Part A

The graph of <math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented.

Determine possible coordinates <math alttext="open parentheses t comma h open parentheses t close parentheses close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> for the five points: <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>.

5 points are on the graph as follows:

Point F is at the first peak.

Point G is on the midline between the first peak and the first trough.

Point J is at the first trough.

Point K is on the midline between the first trough and the second peak.

Point P is at the second peak.

frqParts.text:
Part A

The graph of <math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented.

Determine possible coordinates <math alttext="open parentheses t comma h open parentheses t close parentheses close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> for the five points: <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>.

5 points are on the graph as follows:

Point F is at the first peak.

Point G is on the midline between the first peak and the first trough.

Point J is at the first trough.

Point K is on the midline between the first trough and the second peak.

Point P is at the second peak.

topic.text: 3.7: Sinusoidal Function Context and Data Modeling

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
